conversation.content: Hmm, how is it theorized?

There are several competing theories, and it's still pretty hotly debated! Here are the main theoretical frameworks:
Life Cycle Evolution Theory (Grosberg & Strathmann): They propose that early multicellular organisms evolved alternating life cycles - a multicellular "soma" phase for growth and feeding, alternating with a unicellular "germ" phase for reproduction and dispersal. Over time, the unicellular bottleneck becomes more and more constrained until you get the familiar pattern of most cells losing reproductive potential.
Evolutionary Transition Theory (Maynard Smith & Szathmary): Focuses on how to suppress within-group competition. They argue you need mechanisms like "policing" (cells that detect and destroy cheaters) or simple physical constraints that make cheating impossible.
Kin Selection Models: Since all cells in a clone are genetically related, Hamilton's rule predicts they should cooperate. But you still need to explain how some cells evolve to completely give up reproduction rather than just reduce it.
Environmental Bottleneck Models: Maybe harsh conditions periodically killed most cells in a colony, leaving only a few to restart. Over evolutionary time, organisms evolved to "anticipate" these bottlenecks by programmatically reducing to reproductive cells.
Recent experimental work with organisms like Chlamydomonas and slime molds is actually testing these theories! Researchers can watch multicellularity evolve in real-time and see which mechanisms emerge.
The consensus seems to be that multiple mechanisms probably worked together - kin selection + developmental constraints + environmental pressures. But we're still missing the "smoking gun" of exactly how that first transition happened.

conversation.content: How did these become fish?

Now we're jumping across hundreds of millions of years of evolution! From sponges to fish is an epic journey through some of biology's greatest innovations.
After sponges, the big breakthrough was bilateral symmetry - animals that looked the same on left and right sides, with distinct front and back ends. This allowed for directed movement and concentrated sensory organs at the "front." Think early flatworms.
Then came the coelom - a body cavity that allowed organs to move independently of the body wall. This was huge for developing complex internal structures and more sophisticated locomotion.
The next major leap was the evolution of chordates - animals with a notochord (flexible rod down the back), a dorsal nerve cord, and pharyngeal slits. Early chordates like Pikaia from the Cambrian looked like swimming pickles with these key features.
The vertebrates evolved when the notochord was replaced by a segmented backbone made of vertebrae. Early jawless fish like Haikouichthys (around 520 million years ago) had this innovation.
But the real game-changer was jaws! Early fish were filter-feeders, but jaws (evolved from gill arches) opened up predatory lifestyles. Dunkleosteus and other placoderms became massive armored predators.
Then came paired fins for better maneuverability, swim bladders for buoyancy control, and gradually the sleek, efficient body plans we recognize as "fish."
What's amazing is how each innovation built on the last - bilateral symmetry enabling directed movement, coeloms enabling organ complexity, backbones enabling larger size and better locomotion, jaws enabling new feeding strategies. Each step opened up new evolutionary possibilities!
